div.l: Til it be roten in mullok or in stree
We olde men I drede / so fare we
Til we be roten / can we not be rype
We hoppen alwey / while the world wol pipe
For in oure wil / ther stiketh eủere a nayle
To haue an hoor heed / and a grene tayle
As hath a leek / for though oure myght be goon
Oure wille desireth folye eủere in oon
For whan̄ we may noȝt done / than wol we speke
Ȝit in oure asshen olde / is fire yreke
Foure gledes have we / whiche I shal deuise
Auᵃauntyng lying / anger and couetise
Thise foure sparkles longen vnto elde
Oure olde lymes / may wel ben vnwelde
But wille shal not faylen / that is soth
And ȝit have I alwey / a coltes toth
As many a ȝere / as it is passed henne
Syn that my tappe of lyf bygan to renne
For sikerly / whan I was born̄ anoon̄
Deth drough the tappe of lyf and let it goon̄
And euer sithen / hath the tappe yronne
Til that almost / al empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf now droppeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge may wel rynge and clymbe
Of wrecchednes / that passed is ful yore
With ode folk / saue dotage is more
Whan that oure host / hadde herde this ʆsermonyng
He gan forto speke / as lordly as a kyng
He seide what amounteth al this witte
What shal we speke al day of holy writte
The devel made a Reve / forto p̉reche
Or of a Souter a Shipman or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie nouȝt the tyme
Lo depford / and it is almost pryme
Lo Grenewich / that many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
Now sires / qduod this Oswold / the Reve
I pᵃray you all / that ye nouȝt you greve
